Records]] | associated_acts = [[Duke Ellington]], [[Johnny Hodges]] | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Lawrence Brown''' (August 3, 1907 – September 5, 1988) was an acclaimed [[jazz]] [[trombonist]] from [[Kansas]] who achieved recognition with the [[Duke Ellington]] orchestra.<ref>[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p8154/biography|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic biography]</ref> Brown worked throughout his career as a [[session musician]] as well as recording his own solo efforts. ==Biography== He began his career with [[Charlie Echols]] and [[Paul Howard (musician)|Paul Howard]]. In 1932 he joined [[Duke Ellington]]. His great technical command of the instrument, with its "creamy tone, neurotic [[vibrato]] and range" was featured with Ellington's band every year in compositions such as "Blue Cellophane" and "Golden Cress." Brown left Ellington's band in 1951 to join a band led by former Ellington [[sideman]] [[Johnny Hodges]], where he stayed until 1955. After leaving Hodges, Brown took a position for five years with [[CBS]] as a [[session musician|session player]]. In 1960, Brown rejoined Ellington and stayed with him until 1970. After leaving Ellington's band the second time at age 63, Brown quit performing completely. Brown fulfilled many roles in the Ellington Orchestra—as a [[ballad]]eer, technical [[Solo (music)|soloist]], and section leader. His highly melodic ballad playing as well as his fast technical style inspired [[trombone|trombonists]] from [[Tommy Dorsey]] to [[Bill Harris (musician)|Bill Harris]]. Brown was married to actress [[Fredi Washington]]. He died in Los Angeles, California. ==Discography== *1955: ''Slide Trombone Featuring Lawrence Brown'' ([[Clef Records]]) *1965: ''[[Inspired Abandon]]'' ([[Impulse!
